userreviews.userReview: Baumeister der welt - Der Kampf mit dem Dämon, Stefan Zweig تاریخ نخستین خوانش: پنجم اکتبر سال 20161 میلادیعنوان: پیکار با دیو : زندگی نامه فریدریش هلدرلین؛ نویسنده: اشتفان تسوایک (سوایک)؛مترجم: محمود حدادی؛ تهران، نیلوفر، 1394؛ در 221 ص؛ شابک: 9789644486319؛ عنوان دیگر: زندگی نامه فریدریش هلدرلین؛موضوع: زندگینامه فریدریش هلدرین (هولدرین)؛ از سال 1770 تا سال 1843 - قرن 20 مفردریش هلدرلین (هولدرین)، متفکر و شاعر هم‌روزگار هگل نام آشنا هستند که در مارس 1770 میلادی به این دنیا آمدند. اهمیت ایشان یک قرن بعد درک می‌‌شود و مارتین هایدگر بر شعر‌های ایشان تفسیری می‌نویسند و از ایشان به عنوان: «شاعر‌ترین شاعر‌ها» یاد می‌‌کنند. هولدرلین ششم ژوئن سال 1843 میلادی از این دنیا رفتند. در توضیح پشت جلد کتاب: پیکار با دیو؛ چنین آمده است: هلدرین در نامه ‌ای به مادرش، در توجیه زندگی شاعرانه ‌ی خویش می‌نویسند: « نمی‌توان دانشمند یا بازرگان بود و در عین حال شاعر هم. در آن صورت یک مقصود قربانی مقصود دیگر می‌شود. کوتاهی در شغل، فرار از مسئولیت در قبال دیگران است، و کوتاهی در هنر، گناه در حق ودیعه ‌ای خدایی. آتش مقدس رسالت را نمی‌توان در حد شعله ‌ی اجاق خانه پایین آورد. »؛ شاعر می‌خواست پاکبازانه همسو با هویت خویش زندگی کند. پایداری بر این اصل – آن هم در روزگار غربت هنر – راز ماندگاری شعر ایشانست، و همزمان فاجعه‌ ی سرنوشت ‌ایشان نیز. آثار ترجمه شده از هولدرین: گوشه ‌نشین در یونان هیپرپون، فریدریش هلدرلین، مترجم: محمود حدادی، ناشر: نیلوفر، 1391؛ عنوان: شعر و شهود: تفسیر هفتاد اثر تغزلی آلمانی، گردآوری: محمود حدادی؛ ناشر: پژواک کیوان ؛ عنوان: نیتِ خیر: مترجم: بیژن الهی، ناشر: نشر بیدگل؛ عنوان: آنچه می‌ماند، مترجم: محمود حدادی؛ ناشر: نیلوفر، 1393ا. شربیانی

The take-home message is read everything Zweig ever wrote. Jeez. Such flowing, insightful, lucid prose, like a faucet streaming graceful intelligence across and down the pages. A good book for November's melancholic seasons of mist and mellow fruitfulness. Holderlin the ethereal poet, Kleist the restless exaggerator, Nietzsche the inspired light. Totally compelling across the board biographical essays on creative genius and madness. Goethe comes up all the time as a sort of rational gubernatorial foil to these inspired/possessed folks. Like all psych portraiture, the fun part is self-IDing shared traits. In each case, Zweig writes about them because they're off-the-chart extremes -- and again (I'm thinking of Bernhard's "art of exaggeration" in Extinction: A Novel) it's exaggeration that always seems so essential for powerful creation, as long as it's hyper-truthful. More true than truth. Zweig's portraits are exaggerated most likely too -- these guys come off as legends, mystics, saints, proto tragic rock stars. But never did I think he was overdoing it, or maybe every once in a while when talking about Nietzsche. But again the thing I'll most remember about this one is that it will lead me to read all of Zweig (particularly his biographies) and Kleist and most of Nietzsche. Holderlin doesn't interest me too much, although I may have enjoyed his section the most. Anyway, a great literary biography -- recommended to anyone frazzled by trying to write etc. Interesting that for so many writers I know it's not a spiritual struggle so much as a struggle for a shred of success, struggles regarding whether or not to self-promote, self-publish, sell-out and write something that (as Bill Hicks says) sucks Satan's cock -- it's refreshing therefore to read about these writers' old-fashioned struggles with art and inspiration.

Zweig'ın dili her ne kadar akıcı olsa da, ağır bir kitap oldu. Fakat çok şey kattı diyebilirim, biyografi türünde olabilir ancak Hölderline, Kleist, Nietzsche, hepsinin hayatları içlerindeki şeytanla mücade etmek ve bu uğurda tükenmekle geçmiş. Bu savaş biyografiden çok öykü gibi. Özellikle Kleist'dan çok etkilendim. Hölderline'ı okurken boğuldum ve Nietzsche beni delirtti. Zweig'ı okumuş olan bilir, kelimeler ne derece kifayetsiz kalıyor biz yazmayı deneyince. En çokta içimizdeki şeytan susunca.

I have little enough time for writing this review. So I won't. But what I can tell you is that this book is a fine and perfect example of great writing. Zweig is a master at teaching and expressing his thoughts clearly and he is so very interesting in his approach to this (and any) subject. Though he was profiling three great artists of their own particular time in Holderlin, Kleist, and Nietzsche, Zweig was primarily instructing us on the daemon, which is a word I had heard prior to this reading but never had it explained to me in such clear and precise language. Now, at least, I know what is wrong with me, or what is right, depending on your own personal perception of the artist's drive. How frustration and unhappiness continue to press us on to better work and more serious incisions into our consciousness. This book is amazing on so many levels. To say I loved it would be an inadequate expression of my feelings for it. It is a precious and important work written by a man who was such a great writer and thinker. Zweig certainly did justice to the good and lasting memory of these three subjects, misunderstood and rejected in their own time, but who now live on in immortality as the great writers they really were. The fact that all three were social outcasts was basically by their own design, and it offered them the opportunity to perfect their work privately in a most violent and disruptive way that is scary and a threat to those of us who are delusional in the comforts of our daily living. Truth is, the world is always in chaos and we better not ever forget it.

"كل فن يحتاج إلى الاضطراب حافزاً للصياغة والتشكيل ولكن حاجته إلى هدوءٍ سام يقوم على التفكير والتقدير للموازنة النهائية سعياً وراء الاكتمال ." ستيفان تسفايج.يسلط تسفايج الضوء على عدد من الشخصيات المؤثرة في خلق الأدب، وكذا في تخليق ألواناً من التغيير في العالم الواقعي أيضاً، لينتج الإنسان الجديد عن طريق الفن، من أجل بشرية جديدة. تنتمي هذه الشخصيات إلى عصر الإنسانية الكلاسيكية. وذلك عبر تحليله المعمق للتفاصيل؛ اتبع المذهب الفينومينولوجي، والتفسير المنهجي والنقدي (كالنموذج المعرفي العقلاني والتأملي) كما أجاد في تفكيك الإنسان.+ اعتنائه بالإخصاب المادي- الحسي، وبعلله الظاهرية، وبفلسفة الجمال (استكشاف وبحث الأنساق المفهومية لالتقاط النفس الجمالي.)، مع إحاطته بالبعد الإنساني والتاريخي لكل شخصية . هذا الكتاب مدخل رائع في التعرف على سيرة حياة، وأعمال رسل الأدب: ( هولدرين- دوستويفسكي - بلزاك - ديكنز- تولستوي - ستندال- كلايست.) ستيفان تسفايج كاتب أدبي رفيع، ولغوي عبقري، تميَّز في رقة إحساسه وحدة ذهنه في الوقت ذاته ؛ وهو قارئ هندسي- فكري- فني- نفسي عظيم .

There do exist such sort of books which you open to discover, but can't continue reading - you close it because of its tough and severe topic, because of the durable agony of its characters. However, on one sunny day you suddenly realize that it would be better for you to go on reading it till the end. It whispers that there is something hiding behind that will definitely help you to encounter the troubles and can light up a little candle on your dark suspicions about the world injustice towards people. You can not figure it out - why talented, genius people have to suffer this much in their entire life? Why the people who enlight our path or our journey to the light of truth have to be faced with the most merciless sides of life?And the last question is......Why these people are so alone?Maybe, no human-being can embrace them as firmly as they embrace the wisdom of existence.Excellent.

این کتاب بخشی از کتاب بزرگتری است که تسوایگ درباره ی هاینریش فون کلایست، نیچه و هلدرلین نوشته است. لحن کتاب بسیار شاعرانه و شکواییه گون است. شعرهایی از هلدرلین نیز جابجا در کتاب نقل شده اند. مترجم نامه هایی از هلدرلین و خطاب به هلدرلین به کتاب افزوده است که بسیار خواندنی است. من بیشتر از این نامه ها لذت بردم. در انتها گاهشمار زندگی هلدرلین نیز آمده است. و اما، درباره ترجمه.شخصا به ترجمه های حدادی علاقه مندم. ولی این ترجمه ایرادهایی دارد که نگفتنشان جایز نیست. یک: کماکان نمی دانم چرا هولدِرلین را ایشان هلدَرلین و هردِر را هردَر می‌نویسند! دو: چرا با اینکه استاد آلمانی اند، یک بار ژان پل و بار دیگر ژان پائول می نویسند! سه : چرا اینقدر غلط املایی در متن و پانویس ها هست؟ چهار: بعضی جملات خیلی غیرفارسی اند، اگرچه تردیدی در توانایی های ادبی متزجم وجود ندارد. پنج: "تفاوت از" ظاهرا غلط است، باید نوشت "تفاوت با!"مدرباره هلدرلین: من او را دوست دارم. هم اشعارش را، هم طرز زندگی اش را، هم عشقش به یونان باستان را. به نظر من، هلدرلین بسی بزرگ تر از هگل و شلینگ، هم حجره ای هایش در دیر توبینگن، است. دلیلش هم آن تفکر ناخودآگاه و جبلی ای است که در سلوک و اشعار او آشکار است. از نظر شخصیتی هم جذابیت بیشتری برایم دارد. از تسوایگ تا به حال چیزی نخوانده بودم. راستش خیلی راضی نیستم از کتابش.

I'm really bad at wrtinig rewievs, but for this book, I'll force myself to give it a try.Book is divided on three parts, each describing life and work of a great German writer, philosopher.I don't know what it is about the author's style, but for some reason, every sentence you read, feels like a quotation. The translation is wonderful and inside of it you can feel the pride, beauty and gentlesness (i don't really care if this is an english word or not) of german language. To me, the book was wonderful because for some time I've been studying Holderlin's, Kleist's and Nietzsche's philosophy and it makes your whole concept of what you thought the person was, complete. Overall, the book is beautifully written and it gives you a lot of pleasure while reading it. Definatelly a work of art you'll read more than one time. :)

Böyle bir kitabı ancak Zweig gibi yine kendisi ile savaşan bir sanatçı yazabilirdi herhalde. Başkalarına ait engin ruhların derinliklerinde dolaşabilen ve bunları aktarmaya davranan bir insan olarak önce kendisi, kendisi ile savaşmış olmalı bana göre. Yazar kitapta üç büyük insanın sıradan biyografilerini kaleme almak yerine onların, sislerle kaplı labirentlerde gizlenmiş ruhlarına ulaşmamız için elinden geleni yaparken kendi ruhundaki savaştan etkilenerek bunu yapmış şüphesiz. Zweig, usta, hatta kendisi ile savaşmış bir yazar da olsa, Nietzsche ya da Hölderlin gerçekten onun anlattığı gibi mi hissetmişti? Bundan kimse emin olamaz bana göre. Nietzsche ile ilgili bölümü okurken şunu düşündüm : eserlerini tam olarak okuyamamış okuyucular olarak, bir bütün içinden cımbızla çekilip facebook’ta yayınlanan, Nietzsche aforizmalarını sanki önünü arkasını tam olarak anlamış gibi başkaları ile paylaşmayı ne kadar hak ediyoruz? Kim ya da hangi düşünce akımı, sadece, kendi ile savaşı sürecinde ortaya attığı, sonra yine kendisinin çürüttüğü fikirleri yansıtan bu aforizmalara bakarak Nietzsche’yi sahiplenebilir? Kim sadece bu aforizmaları işarete ederek “işte Nietzsche de kesinlikle bunu savunuyordu” diyebilir ki? Ayrıca, kimbilir, anlaşılabilir olan ancak insanların işine gelmediği için görmezlikten gelinen daha ne aforizmaları vardır Nietzsche’nin. Bunu anlamak için tüm Nietzsche eserlerini kronolojik olarak okumak gerekir.Zweig’ın yazdığı bu kitabın içeriğini anlamak kolay olmasa da alışıla gelmiş sürükleyicilikten farklı anlamda bir sürükleyiciliğe sahip. İnsan okurken, belki de bir sonraki satırda sisi aralayacağım diye düşünerek sürükleniyor cümlelerin peşinde.Yazar üç büyük insanı, biraz da, Goethe’nin onlara nasıl benzemediğinden yola çıkarak anlatıyor. Böylece özellikle Nietzsche ve Hölderlin’i anlatımında, her ikisini de Goethe ile kıyaslayarak düşüncelerini daha somut kılarken aynı zamanda Goethe hakkında da okuyucuyu bilgilendirmiş oluyor.Ortak acıları en yakınları tarafından bile anlaşılmamak olan üç insan (Kleist, Nietzsche, Hölderlin) kendi yurtlarından bile olmayan kimi okuyucular tarafından nasıl merak edildiklerini görseler kimbilir ne kadar mutlu olurlardı!

Libro altamente recomendable para todos aquellos que estén interesados en la literatura alemana. Zweig nos cuenta con su poesía en forma de prosa de nuevo de una manera que engancha cómo veían el mundo estos grandes autores. Es, sin duda, una lectura agradable, amena y enriquecedora.

Più che una biografia, questa di Zweig è un immenso affresco, una sublime, appassionata sinfonia.L’Hölderlin descritto da Zweig è l’antitesi del giovane angelico, dai tratti delicati e miti immortalati nel dipinto “ufficiale”.Coevo della giovane generazione di poeti ed artisti che si affaccia sul nuovo secolo, è l’unico a sopravvivere alla furia del destino (“mai l’altare degli Dèi fu bagnato di tanto sangue divino”): André Chénier, John Keats, Byron, Shelley, Novalis, Kleist, Schubert, Leopardi, Bellini, Puschkin… nessuno di loro arriva a quarant’anni.“Uno,uno solo della sacra schiera, il più puro, rimane ancora a lungo sulla terra senza più Dèi […] Come accadde a Tiresia, il veggente, gli Dèi gelosi non hanno ucciso colui che ha spiato i loro segreti, ma si sono limitati ad accecargli lo spirito”.Divorato dal demone della poesia e da un destino ineluttabile, incompreso dagli amici, Hölderlin soccombe infatti precocemente alla follia.“Solo la morte può salvare quel che c’è di sacro nel poeta, il suo intatto entusiasmo non contaminato dalla vita; solo la morte può eternare la vita in un mito”.Il 7 giugno 1843 lo portano fuori dalla sua ultima prigione terrena e lo calano in terra, dimenticato. Centinaia di suoi scritti vengono gettati via, considerati illeggibili, prodotti grafici di un monomane pazzo.Pochi mesi prima, a Parigi, un altro signore semisconosciuto, colpito da apoplessia, cade sul Boulevard des Italiens e nessuno prende nota della sua morte. E’ un certo monsieur Beyle: Stendhal. Come accadde per Hölderlin, si portano alla biblioteca di Grenoble decine di ceste piene di manoscritti. Roba senza valore di un grafomane.“Così, con uguale indifferenza, due generazioni disperdono il messaggio del più grande fra i prosatori francesi, del più grande fra i lirici tedeschi […] a riconoscerli ambedue come suoi progenitori fu soltanto Nietzsche, lo spirito più chiaro, il più veggente che mai sia vissuto tra noi”.

 Rimbaud gibi.Zweig, ozellikle 
 Holderlin de fazlasiyla yanilmisti.Bahsettigi elestiriler kendinden cok baskasinin fikriydi, kaldi ki, Holderlin icin siir yazan

Stefan Zweig es de mis escritores favoritos, de los pocos que me siguen gustando con el paso del tiempo. El único que me ha hecho comprar cuanta biografía, correspondencia, obra de teatro y recopilación oscura aparece. Es una debilidad, no puedo ver su nombre en una portada porque me domina la manía. Debo tener más de veinte títulos dedicados a él, y tal vez unos cincuenta escritos por él, incluyendo sus obras (in)completas. No lo he leído en totalidad, lo dosifico, lo raciono. Esta vez decidí leer “La lucha contra el demonio”, le tenía muchas ganas, iba a ser un nuevo tríptico, un caleidoscopio de la alemania del siglo XIX, pero la verdad me decepcionó un poco. La estructura me gusta, “La curación por el espíritu” me parece una obra maestra, pero lo que brilla en “la curación” le falta a “la lucha”. Incluso siento que la elección de los perfiles es uno de los grandes problemas del libro. Holderlin, Kleist y Nietzsche. Si tuviera que elegir cambiaría a los dos primeros por Goethe y Wagner y creo que la unidad temática no se dañaría en lo absoluto, no todos los demonios son oscuros. Pero esos dos poetas tan disimiles no pueden generar ningún contrapunto con Niezstche, simplemente no están a la altura, se quedan cortos, les falta peso. Y en el libro es evidente, el retrato de Nietzsche es fantástico, los otros dos parecen ejercicios de admiración. En lo personal me gustó más el de Kleist a pesar de lo corto, pero el de Holderlin es una salida en falso. Me entristece porque no sé si me espera otra revelación por Zweig, o tal vez lo mejor de su obra ya lo he leído, prefiero pensar que no, que en sus textos aún me esperan más sorpresas.
Şükür bitti dediğim kitaplardandı. Almanlar şiir ve felsefeyle uğraşmasın. Savaşsınlar...

La lucha contra el demonio comprende tres ensayos biográficos breves sobre genios románticos (sí, estoy en desacuerdo con Zweig respecto a su exclusión de Kleist del movimiento) que, a ojos del autor, crearon una obra sublime desde su impulso demoniaco, sucumbiendo a éste de forma temprana: Holderlin, Kleist y Nietzsche. El libro, más que ofrecer una visión crítica tradicional, desde la semiología, filología y psicología, roza apenas la historiografía elevándose como un elegía desgarradora al genio de estos artistas y, a través de ellos, a toda la generación deslumbrante del cambio de siglo, que refulgió con más fuerza que cualquier otra sólo un instante, que sin embargo logró capturar el infinito, consumiéndose durante la primera mitad del siglo XIX. El libro está escrito magistralmente, en tono lírico que acentúa la melancolía ante esa pérdida, y repleto de anécdotas que agregan colorido a un paisaje de un azul prístino y vaporoso, que es a la vez tributo al canto órfico y la voluntad sobrehumana del artista demoniaco, y lamento por la utopía olvidada, el páramo desolado que nos rodea hoy, la pérdida inminente del Parnaso...

Una excelente transcripción sobre la historia de tres grandes genios de la literatura alemana “Holderlin, Kleist, Nietzsche” Como usualmente me sucede con los libros de Stefan Zeigt, quede inmediatamente atrapado desde que inicia con su planteamiento investigativo sobre esos famosos seres hasta su final donde contemplamos la lucha contra el demonio, esa pelea filosófica y mental que se libra en lo más oscuro y más secreto de nuestra mente, y que viene como el leve soplo de una brisa primaveral y que finaliza en un tumultuoso vendaval, desgarrando todo fundamento de lógica individualista, y cuestionando la existencia humana. Un excelente libro para quienes quieren conocer el pensamiento, y lo que originó la matriz de su locura.

I read this because (a) I'm a Nietzsche junky (who hasn't read all his stuff yet because I want to save it in order to delay the day when I get depressed because there is no more Ubermensch to read [and who still has a hard time spelling his name]) and (b) I've been wanting to read me some Zweig for a while. Zweig did not disappoint in his book on three German writers whose artistic inner daemons ultimately destroyed them. As a bonus, I was introduced to Hölderlin and Kleist, two more writers I have yet to read (isn't it funny that the more you read, the more you realize you have yet to read?). Hölderlin, the poet, lost his mind; being obsessed with poetry. He could not function anymore, but still, somehow could recite brilliant improvised poetry when fans came to see him in his madness. Kleist gave himself completely to his muse (or daemon) and killed himself at his apex, after finally finding a woman willing to die with him. Nietzsche, as we know, was brilliant and mad. The crazier he got, the more brilliant he got until that horse got him. Zweig treats him more as a poet than a philosopher, which I agree with (when I first read Nietzsche it felt more like scripture than philosophy, surprisingly) And interestingly, the author, Zweig also killed himself, being perhaps another casualty of the daemon. Zweig does not write as a literary critic or historian or anything similar. He is pretty dramatic and poetic himself, which suits the subject matter. H may be a little too melodramatic for some readers, but I dug it. I will include a very over-the-top excerpt from the introductory chapter on the Antichrist so you can decide for yourself. Too much?"Such was Friedrich Nietzsche's tragedy, and it had its roots in his utter loneliness. Unexampled was the way in which an inordinate wealth of thought and feeling confronted a world monstrously void and impenetrably silent. Not even an adversary worthy of his steel was vouchsafed him. His indomitable will-to-think had to fall back upon his personal resources; for nowhere but in his own breast could he find answer, and meet with resistance. His all-consuming ardour of thought clung to him like a Nessus shirt, and in order to divest himself of it he tore away strips of his own burning flesh, to stand bared before the ultimate truth, before himself. Icy airs blew upon his nakedness; the cry of his spirit met with stony silence; the leaden skies sank low above the head of this "murderer of God" who, since no opponent was forthcoming, proceeded to attack himself, "a self-slayer, a self-knower, showing no mercy". The daemon within him hounded him out of his world and his day, chasing him to the uttermost marge of his own being."

As others have pointed out, Zweig's beautiful prose would be reason enough to read these portraits, which are more dramatic works of art than biographies, but there is also practical value in this book because to grasp an intuition of the daemon is to delineate the axes and contrasts of literary genius. The themes of isolation, ascension and consumption at the hands of the daemon recur in each of these great "German" writers. The variations and subtleties serve both as cautionary tales and inspiration. Those quotation marks may serve as an example: while all three share the seriousness of the German soul, the daemon provides not only painful isolation but also lofty independence, so those chased by the daemon, like Nietzsche in his flight to the south or Hoelderin forever in the Hellas of poetry, are supra-nationionalists, they are free from religion, society, and "Patriotic strangulation." They answer to a higher compulsion and their respite is not something as small as a nation. If they belong to anything they belong to the sun itself.The tradeoff between the flame and the fuel, the constant flirtation with death, the release into air as music and smoke once there is nothing solid left to burn. These themes unfold at once elegiac and triumphant, always in opposition to the apollonian Goethe, who is more earth than air and fire, successful negotiator and exorcist, tamer of the Daemon.To my mind, identifying Goethe as the appropriate counterpart is the other key insight of the book. It makes clear just how great these consumed souls are. For the opposite of those consumed by the daemon is not simply the uninspired, the salesmen, the everyday conformists. If that were the case the book could have been about Hank Chinaski and the daemon could be replaced by mere intoxication and a penchant for marginal living. No, this is a book about true Genius, the kind you cannot buy with more education or fake with one more hit, the kind that you cannot get rehab out of either, the kind whose stakes are a lifetime of pain and eternity with the gods, the kind that consumes and demands all life-force in itself, by itself, for itself.

Superficial, repetitive arguments that the writers Hölderlin, Kleist, and Nietzsche were possessed and ultimately destroyed by the”daemon,” a higher creative power that drives one out of himself into the elemental. Little or no analysis of their works or lives. Examples from the poetry of Hölderlin give no hint why any attention would ever have been paid to him. Pretty much no examples from Kleist or Nietzsche. Kleist died in a tawdry murder-suicide. Hölderlin and Nietzsche died of actual organic mental illness. Brain disease. Not Zweig make-believe. A most disappointing book, not worth a read.

The stories of Holderlin, Kleist and Nietszsche, who struggled with the 'demon' but produced great art. The passion which drove them to creative highs also destroyed them; or as Zweig puts it "the juices were too plentiful to be contained within the frail rind of man's body. The wine burst the bottle." Poignant, lyrical, Zweig's writing soars & insights apply to many artists & writers today. So erudite, he wonderfully brings these geniuses to life.

Zweig gives a biography of the three great German writers and thinkers, Holderin, Kleist, and Nietzsche. There's a great comparison of their lives of passion and creativity and internal struggles that drove them not only to produce great works, but also led to their mental breaks.

Zweig es muy diferente como novelista y biógrafo, debo decir que en este libro el lenguaje es muy cuidado, pero a veces me parece pomposo y hasta cursi. Sin embargo transmite pasión e invita a conocer la obra de los autores más que dejar una serie de datos

In addition to writing works of fiction, Stefan Zweig was noted for his biographies and non-fiction essays. This book contains three related essays on three German writers - the poet Friedrich Hölderlin, the writer and playwright Heinrich von Kleist, and the philosopher Friedrich Nietzsche. These three have a number of things in common, including a love of "classic" literature and Greece, and more importantly, a streak of madness. Both Hölderlin and Nietzsche went mad at the end of their lives, and Kleist ended his at age 34 in a double suicide. As a fan of Zweig's writing, I was struck that this book is mostly what I would call old-school criticism. For someone who was a close personal friend of Sigmund Freud, the book seems short of a real psychological analysis of the three men. Neither is it an in-depth analysis of their writing. Rather, it comes across as what you might have experienced sitting around after dinner, listening to an erudite friend talk about three people that he considered significant to literary and cultural developments in the 19th century. Taken at that level, it's quite engaging: Zweig was about as erudite a friend as one could possibly want. Yet I always had the feeling that he was stopping short of really getting deeply into these three, preferring to opine rather than analyze. The fact Zweig himself ended his life in a double suicide with his wife brings him closer to Kleist than perhaps he even knew at the time he wrote these essays. All my quibbles aside, language never dies in Zweig's mouth; he's always interesting to read.

Baumeister der Welt ist kein Buch, sondern es sind eigentlich drei. Der erste Band „Drei Meister“ beinhaltet Balzac – Dickens – Dostojewski, der zweite Band „Der Kampf mit dem Dämon“ widmet sich Hölderlin – Kleist – Nietzsche und der letzte Band „Drei Dichter ihres Lebens“ treten Casanova –Stendhal – Tolstoi auf. Trotz der Teile sind alle Personen in Zweigscher Manier dargestellt, also subjektiv personalisiert. Jedes Essay verfolgt weniger eine biographische Gesamtdarstellung der Person, sondern begründet die Pathologie ihres Schreibens. Das Motiv verbindet alle Bände und lässt zugleich ein Triptychon entstehen.

A magnificent character study of three greats in German cultural history, centered around the intriguing motif of struggling with an inner daemon. The use of Goethe as the antimony to these three masters provides an excellent contrast and a thorough, yet not exhaustive, profile of another German cultural father.

description: "The Struggle with the Daemon" is a brilliant analysis of the European psyche by the great novelist and biographer Stefan Zweig. Zweig studies three giants of German literature and thought: Friedrich Hölderlin, Heinrich von Kleist, and Friedrich Nietzsche--powerful minds whose ideas were at odds with the scientific positivism of their age; troubled spirits whose intoxicating passions drove them mad but inspired them to great works.Born in Vienna in 1881, Stefan Zweig travelled widely, living in Salzburg, Austria, between the wars. He enjoyed worldwide literary fame, first as a poet and translator, then as a biographer.
title:
Hölderlin, Kleist, and Nietzsche: The Struggle with the Daemon
      
          (Die Baumeister der Welt #2)
